quest_title: Approximate atomic weight of an element is 26.89. If its equivalent weight is 8.9, the exact atomic weight of element would be
explanation_txt: Atomic weight = Equivalent weight \(\mathrm{\times}\) Valency \[=8.9\times 3=26.7\left({\rm Valency}=\cfrac{{\rm 26.89}}{{\rm 8.9}} \approx 3\right).\]

explanation_plain_text: Atomic weight = Equivalent weight Valency

quest_title: If the sum of two extreme numbers of an A.P. with four terms is 8 and product of remaining two middle term is 15, then greatest number of the series will be
explanation_txt:
Let four numbers are \(a-3d,\, a-d,\; a+d,\; a+3d\).

By given, \(2a=8 \Rightarrow a = 4\) and \((a-d)(a+d)=15\)

\(\Rightarrow \)\(a^{2} -d^{2} =15\)

\(\Rightarrow \)\(d=1\)

Thus required numbers are 1, 3, 5, 7. Hence greatest number is 7.

explanation_plain_text:

Thus required numbers are 1, 3, 5, 7. Hence greatest number is 7.

quest_title: \[\cos ^{-1} \left(\cos \cfrac{7\pi }{6} \right)=\]
explanation_txt: \( \cos ^{-1} \left(\cos \cfrac{7\pi }{6} \right) \\ =\cos ^{-1} \left\{\cos \left(\pi +\cfrac{\pi }{6} \right)\right\} \\ = \cos ^{-1} \left(-\cos \cfrac{\pi }{6} \right) \\ =\pi -\cos ^{-1} \cos \cfrac{\pi }{6} \\ =\pi -\cfrac{\pi }{6} \\ =\cfrac{5\pi }{6} .\)

quest_title: The oxidation state of nitrogen in \(N_{3} H\) is
explanation_txt:

\[{\mathop{N_{3} H} \limits^{*\, \, \, \, \, \, \, \, }} \]

\[3x+1=0,\]

\[3x=-1\]

\[x=-\cfrac{1}{3} .\]

quest_title: Two stones are projected with same initial speed but making different angles with the horizontal so that their horizontal ranges are equal. If angle of projection of one is \(\cfrac{\pi}{3}\) and height \(\text{H}\), then maximum height for another will be
explanation_txt:
\(H=\cfrac{u^{2} \sin ^{2} 60^{\circ}}{2 g}=\cfrac{u^{2}}{2 g} \times \cfrac{3}{4} \)
\(\therefore u^{2}=\cfrac{8 g H}{3} \)
For \(2^{\text {nd }}, \theta=30^{\circ} \)
\(H=\cfrac{u^{2} \sin ^{2} \theta}{2 g}=\cfrac{8 g H}{2 g \times 3} \times\left(\cfrac{1}{2}\right)^{2}=\cfrac{H}{3} \)

quest_title: A negatively charged particle is situated in a straight line joining two other stationary particles each having charge +\(\text{q}\). The direction of motion of -vely charged particle will depend on
ans2_txt: the position at which it is situated
ans3_txt: both magnitude of charge and its position
explanation_txt: If the –ve charge is placed at the centre of line joining two charges +q, then net force on –Q will be zero. If –Q is placed near A and far from B, it will move to A. If it is placed nearly B, it will move to B.

quest_title: The resistance of galvanometer is 25\(\Omega\) and id required 50\(\mu\)A for full scale deflection. The value of shunt resistance required to convert it into an ammeter of 5A is
explanation_txt:
\(\cfrac{\mathrm{i}_{\mathrm{g}}}{\mathrm{i}}=\cfrac{\mathrm{S}}{\mathrm{S}+\mathrm{G}}\)

\(\cfrac{50 \times 10^{-6}}{5}=\cfrac{\mathrm{S}}{5+25}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{S}=2.5 \times 10^{-4} \Omega\)
question_plain_title: The resistance of galvanometer is 25 and id required 50A for full scale deflection. The value of shunt resistance required to convert it into an ammeter of 5A is
ans1_plain_text: 2.5 10
ans2_plain_text: 1.2510

quest_title: A 10 eV electron is circulating in a plane at right angles to a uniform field of magnetic induction 10\({}^{-4}\) Wb/m\({}^{2}\) the orbital radius of electron is
explanation_txt:
\(\text { KE of electron }=10 \mathrm{eV} \)
\(\begin{aligned} \therefore\, & \cfrac{1}{2} m v^{2}=10 \times 1.6 \times 10^{-19} \\ & V=1.875 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{sec} \\ \text { and } \cfrac{m V^{2}}{r} &=e V B \end{aligned} \)
\(r=\cfrac{m V}{e B}=11 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{m}=11 \mathrm{cm}\)

quest_title: One gram of hydrogen is found to combine with 80 \(\textit{g}\) of bromine one gram of calcium valency=2 combines with 4 \(\textit{g}\) of bromine the equivalent weight of calcium is
explanation_txt:
One gram of hydrogen combines with 80 \(\textit{gm }\) of bromine. So, equivalent weight of bromine = 80 \(\textit{gm}\)

\({\mkern1mu\raise4pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu\raise1pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu\raise4pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu} \) 4 \(\textit{gm }\) of bromine combines with 1 \(\textit{gm}\) of \(\textit{Ca}\)

\({\mkern1mu\raise1pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu\raise4pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu\raise1pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu} \) 80 \(\textit{gm }\) of bromine combines with = \(\cfrac{1} {4}\) \(\times\) 80=20

explanation_plain_text:

4 of bromine combines with 1 of

\(\overrightarrow{v_{\mathrm{m}}}=\overrightarrow{v_{\mathrm{r}}}-\overrightarrow{v_{\mathrm{m}}}\)

Now,

\(v^{2}_{1}=v^{2}_{\mathrm{m}}+v^{2} _{\mathrm{m}} \)
\(v_{\mathrm{r}}=\sqrt{3^{2}+4^{2}}=5 \mathrm{km} / \mathrm{hr} \)

\(\begin{array}{ll}{\mathrm{P.E.}=e V} & {\mathrm{P.E.}=\mathrm{K.E.}} \\ {\mathrm{K.E.}=\cfrac{1}{2} m v_{\max } 2} & {e V=\cfrac{1}{2} m v^{2}}\end{array}\)
\(\begin{aligned} v &=\sqrt{\cfrac{2 e V}{m}} \\ &=\sqrt{2\left(\cfrac{e}{m}\right) V} \end{aligned}\)

quest_title:
\(\text{C\(_{2}\)O\(_{4}\)\(^{--}\) }\)undergoes oxidation as \(\text{C\(_{2}\)O\(_{4}\)\(^{--}\)\(\rightarrow}\) \) \(\text{2CO\(_{2}\)}\) + \(\text{2e\(^{-}\)}\)  
 The equivalent wt of \(\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{C}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{4} .2 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}\) is therefore
explanation_txt:
Molecular weight of \(H_2C_2O_4.2H_2O\) = 126

\(\text{Equivalent weight} =\cfrac{\text{Molecular weight}}{\text{Change in ON per mole}}\)

\(\overset{+6}C_2O_4^{--} \to \overset{+4}CO_2 + 2e^-\)

Change in ON per mole = 2

So equivalent weight = 126/2 = 63
question_plain_title: undergoes oxidation as \) + The equivalent wt of is therefore
explanation_plain_text:
Molecular weight of = 126

Change in ON per mole = 2

So equivalent weight = 126/2 = 63

quest_title: A silica bulb can hold 340g mercury at 0\({}^{o}\)c when completely filled. Some steel ball are introduced then remaining space is occupied at 0\({}^{o}\)c by 255g of mercury. On heating to 100\({}^{0}\)c, 4.8g of mercury overflow then linear expansivity of steel if expansivity of silica is negligible (absolute expansivity of mercury = 180\(\times\)10\({}^{-6}\)/\({}^{o}\)c)
explanation_txt:
\(\begin{array}{l}{\text { At } 0^{\circ} \mathrm{C},} \\ {\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{o}}=\cfrac{m}{13.6}=\cfrac{340}{13.6}=25 \mathrm{cc}}\end{array}\)

When steel balls are introduced

\(\begin{array}{l}{\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{m}}=\cfrac{255}{13.6}=18.75 \mathrm{cc}} \\ {\text { Vol. of steel }\left(\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{s}}\right)=25-18.75=6.25 \mathrm{cc}}\end{array}\)

\(\begin{array}{l}{\text { At } 100^{\circ} \mathrm{C},} \\ {(\Delta \mathrm{V})_{\mathrm{a}}=(\Delta \mathrm{V})_{\mathrm{s}}+(\Delta \mathrm{V})_{\mathrm{m}}}\end{array}\)

\(\text { or, } \cfrac{4.8}{\cfrac{13.6}{1+\gamma \times 100}}=\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{s}} \gamma_{\mathrm{s}} \times 100+\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{m}} \gamma_{\mathrm{m}} \times 100\)

\(\begin{aligned} \text { or, } \cfrac{4.8\left(1+180 \times 10^{-6} \times 100\right)}{13.6} &-18.75 \times 180 \times 10^{-6} \times 100 \\ &=6.25 \times \gamma_{\mathrm{s}} \times 100 \end{aligned}\)

\(\begin{aligned} \text { or, } \gamma_{\mathrm{s}}=& 3.48 \times 10^{-5} /^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \\ \alpha &=1.1 \times 10^{-5 / 0} \mathrm{C} \end{aligned}\)
question_plain_title: A silica bulb can hold 340g mercury at 0c when completely filled. Some steel ball are introduced then remaining space is occupied at 0c by 255g of mercury. On heating to 100c, 4.8g of mercury overflow then linear expansivity of steel if expansivity of silica is negligible (absolute expansivity of mercury = 18010/c)
explanation_plain_text: When steel balls are introduced
ans1_plain_text: 5.610/c
ans2_plain_text: 11.610/c
ans3_plain_text: 16.610/c
ans4_plain_text: 22.810/c

quest_title: A small sphere whose mass is 1 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-3}\) gm carries a charge \(\text{q}\) of 2.0 \(\times\) 10\({}^{-8}\) C. It hangs from a silk thread which makes an angle of 30\(\circ\) with a large charged conducting sheet. Calculate surface charge density of the sheet.
explanation_txt:
For conducting sheet

The forces on the spheres are:
\(F=q E\)
Or, \(F=q \cfrac{\sigma}{\varepsilon_{0}}\)
and weight \(m g\)
For equilibrium,
\(T \sin 30^{\circ}=q \cfrac{\sigma}{a_{0}} \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots(1)\)
\(T \cos 30^{\circ}=m g \ldots \ldots \ldots(2)\)
Dividing \((1)\) by \((2),\) we get
\(\tan 30^{\circ}=\cfrac{q \sigma}{\varepsilon_{0} m g}\)
\(\begin{aligned} \therefore \quad \sigma &=\cfrac{\varepsilon_{0} m g \tan 30^{\circ}}{q} \\ \sigma &=\cfrac{8.85 \times 10^{-12} \times 1 \times 10^{-6} \times 9.8}{2.0 \times 10^{-18}} \times \tan 30^{\circ} \\ \therefore \quad \sigma &=2.52 \times 10^{-9} \mathrm{C} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}\)
question_plain_title: A small sphere whose mass is 1 10 gm carries a charge of 2.0 10 C. It hangs from a silk thread which makes an angle of 30 with a large charged conducting sheet. Calculate surface charge density of the sheet.
explanation_plain_text:
For conducting sheet

The forces on the spheres are:

Or,
and weight
For equilibrium,


Dividing by we get
ans1_plain_text: 2.52 10 C/m
ans2_plain_text: 1.52 10 C/m
ans3_plain_text: 4.26 10 C/m
ans4_plain_text: 4.60 10 C/m

quest_title: The approximate hydrogen ion concentration of solution of pH 4.30 (antilog of 0.7 = 5.0 ) is
explanation_txt:
Given,

\(pH=4.3 \\ \begin{align} \Rightarrow [H^+] & = 10^{-4.3}  \\ & = 10^{-5+0.7} \\ &=10^{-5} \times 5 \quad [\because 10^{0.7} \approx 5] \\ &=5 \times 10^{-5}\end{align}\)

explanation_plain_text: Given,
ans3_plain_text: 5 x M

quest_title: When source and observer approach towards each other with half of velocity of sound. The change in frequency detected by observer is
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{f}^{\prime}=\cfrac{v+v_{0}}{v-v_{\mathrm{s}}} \mathrm{f}\)
or, \(\cfrac{\mathrm{f}^{\prime}}{\mathrm{f}}=\cfrac{v+v / 2}{v-v / \mathrm{s}}=3\)
\(\%\) change \(=\left(\cfrac{\mathrm{f}^{\prime}}{\mathrm{f}}-1\right) \times 100 \%=200 \%\)

quest_title: The existence of two unpaired electrons in the silicon atom is in accordance with
explanation_txt:
Hund's rule states that: Every orbital in a sublevel is singly occupied before any orbital is doubly occupied.

This is why 3px and 3py orbitals have single electrons instead to 2 electrons in 3px orbital.
question_plain_title: The existence of two unpaired electrons in the silicon atom is in accordance with
explanation_plain_text:
Hund's rule states that: Every orbital in a sublevel is singly occupied before any orbital is doubly occupied.

This is why 3px and 3py orbitals have single electrons instead to 2 electrons in 3px orbital.
